Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Development of Bio-compatible and Bio-safe Cell Sorters
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project will demonstrate the feasibility of microfluidic-based, bio-compatible, bio-safe, fluorescence-activated cell sorters. Cell sorters are powerful, high-throughput, single-cell characterization and purification tools that are vital for labs in fields such as molecular biology, pathology, plant biology, stem cell biology, and medical diagnostics. Despite their significant impact, current commercial cell sorters have a variety of drawbacks. High instrument costs (average cost: ~$500,000), high maintenance (maintenance cost: ~$30,000 per year; highly trained personnel needed), significant biosafety concerns, and reduction of cell viability and functionality make conventional cell sorters less effective in many applications and inhibit their widespread use. To address limitations of existing cell sorters, an innovative approach is proposed that features two key technologies: 1) a "microfluidic drifting" based cell-focusing technique; and 2) a cell-deflection technique using chirped interdigitated transducers (IDTs). The proposed microfluidic cell sorter eliminates the generation of hazardous aerosols and preserves high cell viability and functions.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project, if successful, will be the development of the most bio-compatible and bio-safe cell sorters for researchers and scientists. According to a 2011 BCC research report, the instrument market for flow cytometers and cell sorters accounted for $1.4 billion in 2010 and is expected to grow at a CAGR of 9.8% from 2010 to 2015 ($2.2 billion). The served available market (SAM) is estimated to be ~$200 million. Compared with the existing cell sorters, the proposed microfluidic cell sorter will have the following advantages: 1) high bio-compatibility; 2) high bio-safety; and 3) low costs and low maintenance. In addition, the cell sorter will be more accessible to researchers and address existing unmet needs in the market (e.g., sorting fragile or sensitive cells while preserving high viability and functions). It will accelerate research findings and improve diagnostics and therapeutics. It will also create more job opportunities as the company grows.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report – NSF Phase I STTR, IIP-1346440, “STTR Phase I: Development of Bio-compatible and Bio-safe Cell Sorters"

PI: Lin Wang, Ascent Bio-Nano Technologies, Inc.

co-PI: Tony Jun Huang, The Pennsylvania State University

Cell sorters are powerful, high-throughput, single-cell characterization and purification tools that are vital for labs in fields such as molecular biology, pathology, plant biology, stem cell biology, and medical diagnostics. Despite their significant impact, current commercial cell sorters have a variety of drawbacks. High instrument costs, high maintenance, significant biosafety concerns, and reduction of cell viability and functionality make conventional cell sorters less effective in many applications and inhibit their widespread use. To address limitations of existing cell sorters, in this STTR Phase I project we have developed an innovative acoustic-based cell sorter. Unlike conventional cell sorters, which use electrostatic deflection as a means of sorting, our acoustic cell sorter uses acoustic waves to redirect and separate cells. It eliminates the generation of hazardous aerosols and preserves high cell viability and functions, making it particularly suitable for sorting sensitive or fragile cells. In this project, we have reached the following three milestones: 1) successfully prototyped a microfluidic flow cytometry unit that can achieve high-resolution cell detection, 2) successfully demonstrated an acoustic-based cell-sorting unit that can sort individual cells from neighboring cells in a continuous flow stream, and 3) successfully integrated and tested an acoustic cell sorter chip that combines the microfluidic flow cytometry unit and the acoustic-based cell-sorting unit.

Ascent Bio-Nano Technologies Inc. offers the most bio-compatible and bio-safe cell sorters for researchers and scientists because of our innovative surface acoustic wave microfluidic technologies. Our acoustic cell sorter have the following advantages: 1) high-biocompatibility; 2) high bio-safety; and 3) low costs and low maintenance. It will be more accessible to researchers and address existing unmet needs in the market (e.g., sorting fragile or sensitive cells while preserving high viability and functions). It will accelerate research findings and improve diagnostics and therapeutics. Due to their importance, the research findings resulted from this STTR Phase I project have been reported by high-profile journals such as Nature Methods and PNAS, as well as by National Academy of Engineering, and more than 1000 public media outlets in countries such as the US, UK, Germany, China, Japan, India, Spain, Peru, Italy, Australia, and Argentina.
